title: 113_s2524
content: The "Pathways to Prosperity Act of 2014" is referenced in the Carl D. Perkins Career and Technical Education Act. The Carl D. Perkins Career and Technical Education Act of 2014 amends Section 3 by redesignating paragraphs and defining a career and technical education program of study as a sequence of academic and technical courses aligned with college and career readiness standards. The Carl D. Perkins Career and Technical Education Act of 2014 defines a career and technical education program of study as a sequence of academic and technical courses aligned with college and career readiness standards. This program should support career readiness skills, progress in content specificity, incorporate multiple entry and exit points with portable demonstrations of technical competency, and culminate in the attainment of an industry-recognized credential or postsecondary education credits. The Carl D. Perkins Career and Technical Education Act of 2014 defines a career and technical education program of study as a sequence of academic and technical courses aligned with college and career readiness standards. This program should support career readiness skills, progress in content specificity, incorporate multiple entry and exit points with portable demonstrations of technical competency, and culminate in the attainment of an industry-recognized credential or postsecondary education credits. The term 'credit transfer agreement' refers to an opportunity for secondary students to be awarded transcripted postsecondary credit, supported with formal agreements among secondary and postsecondary education systems, such as dual enrollment, dual credit, 2-year to 4-year college articulation agreements, or articulated credit, which may include credit awarded for performance on technical assessments. The term 'industry-recognized credential' means a credential that is sought or accepted by employers within the industry. The term 'labor market information' refers to economic, social, and demographic data related to labor markets for assessing labor supply and demand, skills, and competencies. The term 'labor market information' refers to data related to labor markets for assessing skills, competencies, and economic trends to support informed decisions by students, job seekers, employers, and other stakeholders. SEC. 4. ACCOUNTABILITY. Amends Section 113(b)(2) of the Carl D. Perkins Career and Technical Education Act to include measuring the median earnings of students employed after completing a career and technical education program. SEC. 5. NATIONAL ACTIVITIES. Section 114(d)(4)(A) (20 U.S.C. 2324) is amended to include evaluation and technical assistance activities for collecting information on industry-recognized credentials awarded to participants in career and technical education programs. The curr_chunk discusses the requirements for reporting information on industry-recognized credentials awarded to participants in career and technical education programs, including details such as the awarding body, program duration, and number of participants receiving the credential. Infrastructure development for state and local reporting is also emphasized. The curr_chunk emphasizes the need for data sharing agreements with licensing agencies and industry associations, a consistent reporting method across states, and a timely collection system for processing reports on industry-recognized credentials awarded to participants in career and technical education programs. SEC. 6. STATE LEADERSHIP ACTIVITIES. Amends Section 124(b) (20 U.S.C. 2341(a)) to include establishing statewide credit transfer agreements aligned to approved career and technical education programs of study. Section 134(b) (20 U.S.C. 2354(b)) is amended to describe how eligible recipients will partner with business and industry for experiential and work-based learning opportunities, aligning career and technical education programs with community and employment demands. The amendment in section 134(b)(5) requires career and technical education programs to be informed by labor market information and designed to meet labor market projections. Funding under this Act must be coordinated with local resources. The Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 is amended to replace challenging State academic content standards with rigorous, State-identified college and career readiness standards that address academic and career education content. This amendment aligns with the Carl D. Perkins Career and Technical Education Act.
